node.body: Needs some lint fixes? LGTM otherwise.
Can you relocate it higher in the list to keep the list in alphabetical order?

> Can you relocate it higher in the list to keep the list in alphabetical order?

Argh, never mind, it's already not alphabetical, just mostly alphabetical. Anyway, LGTM, but nit: Would prefer to alphabetize the list.

(Also, agree that `n` is probably better. The headers aren't duplicates. They're similarly-named.)
An alternative could be to rename the new arg to `n` ¬Ø\\_(„ÉÑ)_/¬Ø
Please üëç to fast-track since ATM the [daily master job](https://ci.nodejs.org/view/Node.js%20Daily/job/node-daily-master/1448/) is failing

There are some weird errors in CITGM with eslint.
Here is a run on that module with Node 6,8,10 and 11: https://ci.nodejs.org/view/Node.js-citgm/job/citgm-smoker-pipeline/61/console

Edit: fails on earlier versions of Node.js as well.

I put the following notable changes:

```
deps:
  * Updated libuv to 1.26.0.
  * Updated npm to 6.7.0.
http, http2:
  * `response.writeHead` now returns the response object.
perf_hooks:
  * Implemented a histogram based API.
process:
  * Exposed `process.features.inspector`.
repl:
  * Added `repl.setupHistory` for programmatic repl.
tls:
  * Introduced client "session" event.
```

Release build: https://ci-release.nodejs.org/job/iojs+release/4221/

Looks like the previous behavior was to return undefined in `fs.watchFile` call stat objects on Windows when there was an error so that users can check for errors
https://github.com/nodejs/node/commit/ed85c95a9c252071e91bccfaf854d23a2ebe9a2b

> 
> 
> Looks like the previous behavior was to return undefined in `fs.watchFile` call stat objects on Windows when there was an error so that users can check for errors
> [ed85c95](https://github.com/nodejs/node/commit/ed85c95a9c252071e91bccfaf854d23a2ebe9a2b)

I see no reason for Windows to differ from the other platforms with regard to `0` vs `undefined`. I've pushed an update to the documentation (thank you, I hadn't spotted it).

linux-one and windows runs were broken in between.
Resume Build CI: https://ci.nodejs.org/job/node-test-commit/25776/

> 
> 
> The second argument passed to `validate()` and `validateContent()` is not used for anything.

Just noting that `validate()` and `validateContent()` in `test/common/report.js` here in core at the moment are much simpler than their equivalents in the standalone module, which does use the second argument to validate the expected information is included in the report.
I think you may be able to drop the `std::string()` conversions?
Yep, the compiler seems fine with that. Thanks!

Resume CI: https://ci.nodejs.org/job/node-test-pull-request/20645/

EDIT: CI was green.

This is wrapped in `#ifndef _WIN32` because the standalone module wasn't able to access the `node::signo_string` function on Windows since it's not exported (https://github.com/nodejs/node-report/issues/100). In core the guard can probably be removed.
IIRC, the string specified here needs to (or should, according to docs) be exactly the same as the the one included in the precompiled source file. Same for `v8_initializers`.
Can you move these files to `tools/msvs/pch/` and name them `pch_node.cc` and `.h`? Or move the v8 ones into `src` somewhere (is there a logical place?) and name them `v8_pch.cc` and `.h`?

Is this always safe? I see in some files where this is defined other headers are included before. With this here, `NAPI_EXPERIMENTAL` will always be defined, can probably be removed from everywhere in the code.

There is also `NODE_WANT_INTERNALS`. There is and explicit define in `inspector_socket.cc` which will be ignored by all headers pulled by these here.

This might be safe, but is not obvious to me. Might also become difficult to maintain, since anyone not using Windows will only see errors when running CI (if at all).

I guess putting them all in `tools/msvs/pch/` makes the best sense...
Moved & renamed.
This works perfectly as is ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è and it allows reusing in order to add to sources.
P.S. this also reduce divergence between "dev" builds (no LTCG) and "release" builds (with LTCG), as now they both use pch.

This should probably be semver major to be safe. I don't expect anything to break, but wouldn't be surprised if there were differences compiling modules or with performance. In my benchmarking of the PCH we have now, I noticed somethings were faster and some slower, by small margins, and I'm not sure how conclusive that was.

@bzoz can you take a look at the linking changes here?
So on windows run `vcbuild.bat` will be much more faster after this patch get merged, right ?

> So on windows run `vcbuild.bat` will be much more faster after this patch get merged, right ?

ü§û that's the dream

Since there should not be any explicit breaking changes, maybe we can commute the `semver-major` to `dont-land-on-*`?

/CC @nodejs/tsc 

tl;dr this cuts build time on Windows by ~70%

> Since there should not be any explicit breaking changes, maybe we can commute the `semver-major` to `dont-land-on-*`?

SGTM
SGTM. I added it, so I went ahead and changed it. Actually only the commit `build,win: always build with PCH` should be affected by this, and that only preemptively.
Include `<netdb.h>` and `<sys/param.h>` to get the definition of `MAXHOSTNAMELEN`, see src/node_os.cc.
This is V8 issue. Can you report it there?

I haven't traced through the C++ side here, but Isuspect that in the async case, .oncomplete is called with an arg, a status. It happens that afterShutdown() doesn't use it ATM, but if it ever did, this sync call here would be wrong for not passing success/`0`. Maybe it would be better for afterShutdown() to add the arg, and then comment that its not used?

It looks like this file was deleted upstream in [October last year](https://github.com/v8/v8/commit/ebd070ec2f94a6834190606b5d31cdf8f193d38a#diff-3ed9b21ff0ad2ecba12f586efa3f0089). I'll back this change out in any case.
Sure, I can make that change.
files in the deps folder should be modified by submitting a patch to the relevent upstream project. the other stuff looks fine.

`tools/cpplint.py` is also periodically merged from upstream. We have to maintain patches, so probably better to have as few as possible. It looks like the regex there is allowing chars by accident that are not syntactically possible in C++, so are caught by compiler. That should likely be upstreamed to https://github.com/cpplint/cpplint/ and we'll get it back next time we sync to upstream.

/cc @refack (last person who synced cpplint)

Release build: https://ci-release.nodejs.org/job/iojs+release/4188/
@sam-github yes, please. If you can give me a sentence for the changelog I will abort the release job and add it.

> OpenSSL has been updated to 1.1.1a, which is API/ABI compatible with the previous OpenSSL 1.1.0j. Note that while OpenSSL 1.1.1a supports TLS1.3, Node.js still does not.

^-- OK?
This needs to be moved to before `glibcVersionCompiler` to match the changes in this PR.
does this compile on Windows? I think it uses `GetProcAddress`.
Indent error (or does this come from upstream?)
Google favors is 2 space indentation. There is a pretty good chance that this code was formatted with https://github.com/google/yapf

All white-space changes are lifted verbatim from https://github.com/cpplint/cpplint/blob/3d8f6f876dd6e3918e5641483298dbc82e65f358/cpplint.py

P.S. I'll refactor the commits to make that easier to review

> It would also be cool to use `uv_os_uname` now that we have it, I assume?

Yes, I'd like to do that. There are some differences to reconcile, and it would be nice to use it for Windows as well. Definitely something to do before it graduates from experimental, or not at all IMO.

@cjihrig - is there any best practice of precedence on this? (not requiring common and suppressing error thereon) All over the test case I see `common` being required irrespective of its use?

For files in `test/common` directory, it's done the way @cjihrig is doing it here. 

```console
$ grep -l 'eslint-disable node-core/required-modules' test/common/*
test/common/arraystream.js
test/common/benchmark.js
test/common/countdown.js
test/common/dns.js
test/common/duplexpair.js
test/common/fixtures.js
test/common/heap.js
test/common/hijackstdio.js
test/common/http2.js
test/common/index.js
test/common/index.mjs
test/common/internet.js
test/common/tls.js
test/common/tmpdir.js
test/common/wpt.js
$ 
```

Optional suggestion to make it more concise and reduce use of passive voice. Use it if you like it and ignore it if you don't.

```markdown
An artificial error object used to capture the call stack for diagnostic reports.
```

Suggestion: this could also be simplified to e.g.,:

```js
report.onUnCaughtException(er ? er.stack : undefined);
```

I am getting this warning when compiling:

```
../src/node_report.cc: In function ‚Äòvoid report::PrintSystemInformation(report::JSONWriter*)‚Äô:
../src/node_report.cc:778:58: warning: format ‚Äò%llu‚Äô expects argument of type ‚Äòlong long unsigned int‚Äô, but argument 4 has type ‚Äòrlim_t {aka long unsigned int}‚Äô [-Wformat=]
         snprintf(buf, sizeof(buf), "%llu", limit.rlim_max);
                                            ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~^
```

I would fix this myself, but it seems like that would inevitably conflict with this fix. So could you either add `static_cast<>()` with the appropriate values everywhere, or (preferably) use `std::to_string` everywhere?
Thinking about it even more ‚Ä¶ I don‚Äôt see any reason for these values to be strings to begin with. We should probably just store them as `double`s and emit them into JSON that way directly?
@addaleax can you check out the most recent commit (https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/25597/commits/6b0314f6803e202caaf9cd3bdc2123feffcd6e01)?

The change LGTM, but as @seishun says in the other thread ‚Äì it shouldn‚Äôt do anything at all? Along the lines of https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues/25593#issuecomment-455894468: This shouldn‚Äôt be an issue when the definitions are all in one file, and it‚Äôs likely that something else is going on here‚Ä¶
Let's not make magical workarounds. We should figure out why this is happening and (most likely) submit a bug report to Visual Studio.

I agree this is "magical". AFAICR that is why I didn't submit a PR with this till now.
But, it fixes the problem at hand so ¬Ø\\_(„ÉÑ)_/¬Ø
If the underlying issue in the compiler is not fixed then it might break in another way in the next version.

>we need to do something to make Node work again

FYI it works - just not the debug build.
In any case, the commit message should explain what the problem is and how it's being mitigated.
The [problem](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/432157/dynamic-initializers-out-of-order.html) is now "Under Investigation" so maybe it will be fixed very soon.

@refack I think with an updated commit message this should be ready to go :+1: 

(And I‚Äôm assuming we want to merge this even if it gets fixed in the compiler itself)

>(And I‚Äôm assuming we want to merge this even if it gets fixed in the compiler itself)

I don't think so - I find it slightly more readable when an instance definition follows the class definition.

I've tested `master` with the VS2019 preview (`CL.EXE` version `19.20.27027.1`), and it seems like the compiler issue does not reproduce...
But IMO this PR is low impact enough to meanwhile be a beneficial workaround (Node 10 & 11 are built with VS2017).

> Are there notable changes?

The full changelog for the release is available [here](https://github.com/libuv/libuv/blob/a9e6cc7b9967308cac61414aa907070412461c8f/ChangeLog#L1-L49). Changes that might be notable to Node:

- [`ibmi: return EISDIR on read from directory fd`](https://github.com/libuv/libuv/commit/91ca6788bbed45e758ee2744a61f8cf455932763) fixes https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues/25433.
- Automatic retry of failed `uv_fs_rename()` calls on Windows was [reverted](https://github.com/libuv/libuv/pull/2122).

I would suggest not adding this one yet:

[736349c7e3] - build,test: fail coverage target if tests fail (Refael Ackermann) #25432

We've not had good coverage builds since then and so it might be worth holding off on this until we understand that.

First release since our server problems, cross fingers and give a holler on IRC if anything goes wrong. You'll need to reset your host key or you'll get errors running the release script (not fatal errors, you can fix and re-run). `ssh direct.nodejs.org` and fix warnings until there are none and you're just prompted for password.

I'd consider putting this one with the notable changes:

[91015918d8] - deps: upgrade npm to v6.5.0 (Jordan Harband) #25234

The `>` tells GYP to use ["late variable expansion"](http://gyp3.org/docs/InputFormatReference.html#variable-expansions----), which is required because this is in a `target_defaults` clause which is resolved before the top level `variables` clause. Using a `<` for early resolution fails GYP ¬Ø\\_(„ÉÑ)_/¬Ø

If after refactoring everything we can reduce the usage of `aix_variant_name`, I'll try to move it back to a closer scope.
It'll probably be evident in the CI, but we need to pass `-maix64` to the linker as well as the compiler.

I do not understand the PR description, tbh ‚Ä¶ the number of chunks should not be as relevant as the number of buffers ‚Äì and as we are trying to re-use buffers as much as possible in the `ReadStream` implementation, I don‚Äôt think an 8√ó memory overhead would be within expected limits?
ok, I got your response in the main issue; so will have a look and follow your suggestion, thanks.
@gireeshpunathil Okay, I think we basically figured out the same things :) So yeah, the issue is that we have too many concurrent reads for too little actual content.

(We may want to think about a strategy to fix this in the stream implementation itself, btw ‚Äì It‚Äôs not great that 100 concurrent reads allocate 100 full-sized buffers. I‚Äôm not sure how to work around that, though.)

@addaleax - pushed a change to that effect; ptal. minor deviation is in terms of `N` : 
```
N = (pool size) * (concurrent reads) / (file size)
  = 65536 * 6 / 170
  = 2313
```
so I took 2000 on the safer side.
Shouldn't this be in a separate test?
I don't think so. We don't have separate testing for `tools/eslint-rules/rules-utils.js` (nor do I think we need it at this point).

> we should probably migrate the codebase to using printf() style placeholders, and avoid template strings and string concatenation in debug() calls. It might be a good Code and Learn activity.

:heart: I am definitely :+1: on that.

I think template strings are a lot more JavaScript-y than printf-style replacement, so I would be against doing this in places where it's not causing runtime overhead.

```suggestion
`util.inspect()` is a synchronous method intended as a
```

Or even:

```markdown
`util.inspect()` is a synchronous method for debugging.
```

```suggestion
debugging tool. Its maximum output length is approximately 128 MB.
```

```suggestion
Inputs that result in larger output will be truncated.
```

Putting all the suggestions together:

```markdown
`util.inspect()` is a synchronous method for debugging.
Its maximum output length is approximately 128 MB.
Inputs that result in larger output will be truncated.
```

I am not sure if `object insertion order` is something everyone will understand (but neither the former description). What about:

```
The `sorted` option ensures that the object properties insertion order does not
impact the result of `util.inspect()`.
```
The `mainly intended` part was intentional as it's not entirely limited to debugging. I personally would rather keep that or remove the purpose altogether.

I am not sure if the meaning is really clear to people not knowing the option already (the former description does not seem to be ideal either).

What about:

```
If `true`, inspecting `Proxy` objects include the proxies [`target` and `handler`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Proxy#Syntax) objects.
```

That way it also contains a reference to what the `target` and `handler` actually is.
@Trott please see the comment above in response to your suggested edits.

@BridgeAR How about this?:

```markdown
`util.inspect()` is a synchronous method intended for debugging.
```

By re-inserting "intended", we open the door for there being other uses. But by omitting the softener "mainly", we avoid the appearance of *inviting* other uses.

(I'm going so full bike-shed on this one that I feel kind of bad about it, honestly.)

this can easily be accommodated in #25083, but needs to stay separate as:

 - While it shares a common objective and structure, the operating space for the workers in this test is more of JS than C++, and have proven to capture new errors in relation to thread interactions.
 - these tests are sensitive to time, keeping separately makes sure no interference
 - debugging is easy if kept separately.

sorry, it was timeout on AIX!

Interesting story from AIX: In a system where the no. of CPUs are less than 10 (the number of workers in this test), the already spawned workers spin their full allotted time in the JS loop to cause OOM, before main thread gets into action - mostly it was de-scheduled while one or more workers ran. 

So I want to revisit the `while(true)` loop - replace it with a `setInterval` . But before that will need to see what happens in Windows.
@gireeshpunathil Is that normal for AIX/by design, non-preemptive multithreading?

@addaleax - in terms of multi-tasking, there is nothing abnormal; AIX has a truly preemptive kernel.

The difference comes in way of deciding / allocating the `current` CPU post-fork: whether to continue to give it to the parent, or give child a chance and push parent to the next available cpu - only in the current slice of schedule cycle of the current thread of the current process. Since then all processes contend for CPU in a similar manner of Linux, driven by scheduler policies.

While no documented evidence exists, all my experiments has proven that:
 - Linux always runs the parent in the current CPU, consistently.
 - AIX 'mostly' gives it to the child. Reverse is also seen rarely, probably depends on factors internal to the scheduler.

cat tc.c
```c
#include <unistd.h>
#include <stdio.h>
int main() {
  pid_t pid = fork();
  if (pid == 0) write(1, "child\n", 6);
  else write(1, "parent\n", 7);
}
```

linux:
parent
child

```gdb
clone(child_stack=0, flags=CLONE_CHILD_CLEARTID|CLONE_CHILD_SETTID|SIGCHLD, child_tidptr=0x7f824a355a10) = 100129
strace: Process 100129 attached
[pid 100128] write(1, "parent\n", 7)    = 7
[pid 100129] write(1, "child\n", 6)     = 6
```

aix:
child
parent

```gdb
15270132: 100728997: kfork()                            = 18153586
18153586:       kfork()         (returning as child ...)        = 0
18153586:       23462101: kwrite(1, " c h i l d\n", 6)          = 6
18153586:       23462101: kfcntl(1, F_GETFL, 0x20000E0C)        = 67110914
18153586:       23462101: kfcntl(2, F_GETFL, 0x2FF22FFC)        = 67108865
18153586:       23462101: _exit(0)
15270132: 100728997: kwrite(1, " p a r e n t\n", 7)     = 7
```

the same applies to `pthread_create` as well.

In applications of most other languages this does not imply anything: slight difference in terms of CPU allocation, and who gets ahead slightly. But given that `node` threads can run millions of instructions without any blocking calls coming in between, this can cause visible differences in our workloads - such as many timing related issues we usually see in child process related tests.

So in this case one or more workers ate up their remaining slice leading upto OOM before main thread gets a CPU.

So I would like to revert the `while` loop with `setInterval` if you are good with that.
@gireeshpunathil Sure, if you think so. It just seemed pretty odd to me that AIX would act like this/that this could would OOM.
